awd_titl_txt: ABI: Sustaining - MorphoBank: the web tool and database for phylogenetic tree-building with phenotypes and the interpretation of trait evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists understand and interpret the evolution of species by studying both phenotypes (anatomy, behavior, physiology) and genotypes.  The integration of these data, including fossil species, permits the reconstruction of the Tree of Life, which has been identified by Science magazine as one of the 125 top scientific challenges of the new millennium.  By documenting phenotypes for tree-building, researchers test major evolutionary hypotheses such as when did a species develop flowers? Or the ability to fly?  With tens of millions of species on the planet, organizing this informatino requires substantial creative computer infrastructure.  Such infrastructure has existed for genotypic information for some time, initiated in large part by the Human Genome Project in the 20th century.  Organizational tools and databases for phenotypes has not, however, received similar attention historically.  Thus in 2001, with support from the National Science Foundation, investigators initiated MorphoBank (http://www.morphobank.org/), an open-source Web application and database that has become a modern tool for collecting, organizing, storing and presenting data on phenotypes across the Tree of Life.  Because software must continuously change to function in the ever-evolving world of the Internet, this project is to sustain MorphoBank software and infrastructure such that the tool and database endures as a robust resource for the evolutionary biology community and the public.

MorphoBank gives scientists a unique digital workspace to collaborate - in real time - with others worldwide and to conduct data collection relevant to the Tree of Life and evolution.  Prior success of MorphoBank is underscored by key statistics. Each month scientists record >90,000 observations and load >2,000 newly-generated, curated and annotated images.  Over 2,000 visitors reach the site monthly to view projects >3,000 times, matrices >6,000 times, and media >75,000 times. 30% of published projects on MorphoBank are derived from separate NSF-funded geology, biology and anthropology grants.  Another >35% of projects hold the research output funded by scientific agencies internationally making MorphoBank a global destination as a tool and archive.  Scholarship that would have been impossible before MorphoBank includes the NSF-supported Assembling the Tree of Life (AToL) project for mammals.  This research was published in Science and included  >12,000 images tied to hundreds of thousands of scientific observations by a team of over 20 researchers. The paper received wide press (New York Times, BBC, Time Magazine), including mention of MorphoBank as the research-enabling innovation. Morphobank represents a new element in the US scientific infrastructure, providing a model platform for location-independent global scientific collaboration.  Proposed contributions to education and training provided by the current project include: (1) a software course in Web-based bioinformatics for ethnic minority computer science majors from Stony Brook University, New York, (2) two summer internships for selected students from that course, and (3) two "Morpholution" courses at the American Museum of Natural History for high school students to learn scientific practices for studying phenotypes.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the Tree of Life, how all species, living and extinct, are interrelated is a grand challenge of the disciplines of biology and paleontology. Much of the ongoing research on the Tree of Life is based on study of phenotypes, that is, the anatomy or morphology of species. Teams of modern scientists all over the world, whether naming a new species or describing newly understood anatomical information for an existing species, generate thousands of scientifically valuable 2D and 3D images as they conduct their research. These scientists working on the Tree of Life codify their observations about species as text and images in spreadsheets called 'matrices'. To work efficiently, these scientists need shared, real time access to matrices in a web environment as they collect data and need retrospective, archival access to published matrices of their peers.  These archived matrices must be readable by humans and computers.

MorphoBank is the web application and database, supported by this NSF award, that addresses the needs outlined above.  Founded twenty years ago at Stony Brook University, MorphoBank has become an essential resource of the scientific community providing collaborative teams of scientists with private workspaces to collect and share data during research, and a digital archive to share images and text data after they publish a research paper.  This award supported the sustaining of MorphoBank, the development of a permanent business model to support MorphoBank in the future, the training of young scientists in comparative anatomy as used in evolutionary biology, and internships for underrepresented ethnic minority undergraduates to work at the intersection of computer science and biology.

In sustaining MorphoBank this award allowed the team that runs the site to work in partnership with scientific journals to store the underlying data of research. Time was that research papers were not accompanied by additional digital files and digital images, however, with the advent of easy to generate 2D and 3D images, scientists often complete a publication with extensive amounts of digital anatomical data to share with other professionals and the public. 

It is also a modern best practice and professional expectation that the primary data underlying any analytical work by scientists be readily available in human-readable and computer-readable formats and MorphoBank stores and serves such data.  This award supported additional sustaining activies including curation of data, fixing of bugs, upgrades to software, purchase of servers to maintain digital infrastructure and training of new technicians. During the award period the team developed a new voluntary, institutional membership business model in collaboration with the non-profit company Phoenix Bioinformatics.  Under this model the libraries at the universities and museums where scientists use MorphoBank are asked to contribute voluntarily to the ongoing operation of the site.  The development of this model and the plans for technology transfer involved a multi-year negotiation between administrators at Stony Brook University and Phoenix Bioinformatics.  Development and deployment of this business model required modifications to the MorphoBank site including new user policies, new screens to advertise membership and the tracking and billing of member institutions.  These tasks were accomplished by Phoenix Bioinformatics.   At the close of this award 25% of operations costs have been raised and the copyright of MorphoBank has been transferred from Stony Brook University to a new permanent home at Phoenix Bioinformatics: a successful step in meeting the sustainability challenge for this database.

Finally, during this award a class was taught to high school students using the facilities of the American Museum of Natural History.  The students used real anatomical specimens to test scientific hypotheses using MorphoBank under the guidance of scientists.  Additionally, interns from the Stony Brook University Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation developed new code to be integrated into the live MorphoBank site.  In doing this work, these interns were mentored by the MorphoBank scientific and computer engineering team.
